page.title: 04Farming
page.content: Livestock rearing dominates the area. Farmland is mostly permanent pasture, with 12 acres of barley. Eight suckler herds produce beef calves; seven farms produce milk from Friesian cows, collected daily by tanker. Milk quotas were started in 1984. Government compensatory allowances are paid on suckler cows and hill sheep. Two farms let for summer grazing. One farm rears 20,000 broiler chicks from day-old to 43 days. All farms have one or more tractors. Two now have round balers. In summer 1985 when heavy rain for 2 months prevented normal haymaking the grass was salvaged and made big bale silage. Farmers have grazing rights on the fells and commons: 4 sheep per unit (1 acre); 1 cow per unit and 1 pony per 8 units. The commons are owned by the Lake District Special Planning Board.
